title: Inspired design is taking flagship fashion stores to a new level
text:
Radic is known for his neo-Stone Age aesthetic; seemingly primordial structures that appear to have emerged directly from the earth. His Serpentine summer pavilion of 2014, where Burton first experienced his work, was like an oversized, inhabitable megalith installed in Kensington Gardens – turf previously occupied by Zaha Hadid, Rem Koolhaas and Frank Gehry.

The architecture of a store and the fashion it contains, says Radic, “have to be communicating in the same space”.

The McQueen store is a dialogue of contrasts; the rugged, rocky outcrops and sinuous timber sculptures the architect has incorporated into the interior offsetting the rigorous tailoring for which the brand is renowned. At the entrance, two halves of disparate boulders are stacked one atop the other, like a monolithic cracked egg; a fuzz of vibrant blue fabric oozes out from between them.

A monolithic cracked egg: Chilean architect Smiljan Radic’s neolithic touch at Alexander McQueen.

Hard and soft, structured and draped, violently poetic, the store – the first under Burton’s watch – incarnates her intimate understanding of the brand established by her her friend and mentor in 1992 with a graduation collection entitled “Jack the Ripper Stalks His Victims”.

On the top floor, accessed by a spiral timber stairway lined with lush, embroidered silk, Burton has created an experiential space, an active atelier where customers (and students) can encounter archival garments, fabric swatches and reference books, as well as see how the new season’s garments have been conceived.

Large glass cylinders slice through ceilings and floors, creating clear sight lines between the men’s and women’s collections, telescoping the brands history and its future.

Stella McCartney’s Old Bond Street flagship echoes her sustainability principles.

Elsewhere on Old Bond Street, Stella McCartney’s London flagship has made virtue of her sustainability principles, using leftover cruelty-free fur to line the walls. Meanwhile, Victoria Beckham’s store in Mayfair uses concrete to make the space appear more like a gallery than a boutique, although negotiating the fine line between institutional and retail can be a delicate balance.

Advertisement

“A store is not a museum of a brand, it is its daily interface with the customer,” says Pierre Jorge Gonzales of Berlin architectural practice Gonazales Haase AAS, the studio responsible for Balenciaga’s brutally austere boutique on the Rue Saint-Honoré, Paris. “The space you design begins with the vision of the new creative director and is oriented towards the future, not the past.”

Balenciaga’s Paris boutique offers brutal austerity (and scary mannequin artworks).

Gonzales, who is a scenographer, and his partner, architect Judith Haase, were invited by Balenciaga creative director Demna Gvasalia (who also designs cult label Vetements) to reinterpret the historic Parisian house for a new generation. Scraping back the ornamental plaster interior to reveal the building’s bare 19th-century bones, Gonzales and Haase installed gleaming stainless-steel clothes racks and benches – part dry cleaner, part abattoir – upon which to array Gvasalia’s streetwear-inspired fashion.

“Our way of working is to absorb what a designer thinks and stands for, then kind of create a tabula rasa upon which the work can be displayed and understood,” Gonzales says. “What you see is what you get; it is what it is. And this is where we connect with the new generation.” The landmark store is “an almost elemental backdrop for a constantly changing collection”.

At a time when e-commerce is turning shopping into a disembodied experience, savvy brands are flaunting a heavy materiality. Celine is mineral, McQueen geological and Balenciaga elemental, and the aesthetic of the new Mulberry store is – according to its designer Faye Toogood – “midway between the Neolithic age and mid-century brutalism”.

Mulberry’s classic bag, the Somerset, is one of the most copied in British fashion, and named after the county where the bags have been handmade since 1971. Taking inspiration from the English countryside, Toogood has used contrasting materials, scales and volumes to create a compelling new interior topography.

Walls are poured concrete, the floors moss-green ceramic tiles and motley, heather-hued carpet; display units in cast resin appear to flow like water. Cement pillars are “menhir-like”, Toogood says, referring to the monumental standing stones revered by the ancient Celts.

The Mulberry flagship store on Regent Street.

“I wanted the stores to feel more like a welcoming home than a retail environment,” says Toogood, who has also designed interiors for affordable housing in collaboration with Sir David Adjaye. “We have contrasted soft materials; hand-tufted rugs and velvet button-upholstered furniture with glass, ceramic and concrete. These juxtapositions reflect the contrast of the rural and the urban in contemporary Britain. The store aesthetic is a painterly celebration of the national landscape.”

Mulberry creative director Johnny Coca, who studied architecture and then fashion at the prestigious École Boulle in Paris, reckons “buildings and bags have two elements in common: they must be functional and practical. When these factors are just right, then you’ve made a great bag.”

Advertisement

Coca’s brief to Toogood, he says, was to create “immersive environments with the feel of a home, a place to go and explore the modern British identity of the brand.

“The contrast between the English countryside, where our factories are located, and the more industrial side of the cities are part of Mulberry’s DNA and needed to be reflected in the store design. Our stores are not a traditional retail environment; they are inspiring spaces that mix influences and references, a place to rejoice, discover, learn and connect.”

Victoria Beckham’s Mayfair store mimics an art gallery.

With a report by Eventbrite/Harris Group showing that 78 per cent of Millennials prefer to spend their money on experiences over material things, Coca and Toogood – like most people creating bricks-and-mortar retail today – have conspired to make “an experience beyond the product”.

But as Pierre Jorge Gonzales puts it: “First you need an excellent product; then second, the space should give you something more than a simple ‘idea’.”
description: The powerful synergy between architectural permanence and fashion's flightiness is helping luxury labels tell their stories in a tactile manner.
